pageContent:
Welcome to INFO 2950 

(Intro to Data Science)!


Pick up 1 whiteboard, 1 marker, and a 
few tissues (erasers) on your way in. 


Feel free to draw a cat while you wait for class 
to start.

 

 
 
(Make sure to return these at the end of class!)

Why use Virtual Environments?

Why use Virtual Environments?

●
Lots of packages are being actively developed (good!) 
but depend on different versions of each other (bad!)


●
Python isn’t great at dependency management

Multiple dimensions through nested lists of 
arbitrary size

Multiple dimensions, but must be the 
same length

Lists
 vs. 
Arrays

24

Multiple dimensions through nested lists of 
arbitrary size

Multiple dimensions, but must be the 
same length

Indexing multiple dimensions requires  [i][j]

 Indexing multiple dimensions with [i,j]

Lists
 vs. 
Arrays

25

Multiple dimensions through nested lists of 
arbitrary size

Multiple dimensions, but must be the 
same length

Indexing multiple dimensions requires  [i][j]

 Indexing multiple dimensions with [i,j]

Python checks type of each element = SLOW

Python only checks type once = FAST

Lists
 vs. 
Arrays

26

Multiple dimensions through nested lists of 
arbitrary size

Multiple dimensions, but must be the 
same length

Indexing multiple dimensions requires  [i][j]

 Indexing multiple dimensions with [i,j]

Python checks type of each element = SLOW

Python only checks type once = FAST

Requires for loops for operations on each 
element

Can do numerical operations "all at once"

Lists
 vs. 
Arrays

Question: List or Array?

[ 5, “dog”, 7.3 ]



28

琀
琀

Question: List or Array?

[ 5, “dog”, 7.3 ]



29

It includes more than one type 
(integer, string, float), so it is a 
list

Question: List or Array?

[ [ 5, 5, 7 ],

   [ 6, 5, 3 ],

     [ 3, 8, 2 ] ]



30

琀
琀

Question: List or Array?

[ [ 5, 5, 7 ],

   [ 6, 5, 3 ],

     [ 3, 8, 2 ] ]



31

It 
could
 be a list, but it has 
only integers so it can also be 
an array. It has two 
dimensions.

If it is a list, it has three 
elements which happen to 
also be lists.

0-Indexing in Python/Numpy

[ [ 5, 5, 7 ],

   [ 6, 5, 3 ],

     [ 3, 8, 2 ] ]



Numpy: x[0, 2]

Python: x[0][2]

[ [ 5, 5, 7 ],

     [ 3, 8, 2 ] ]



Numpy: x[
_
, 
_
]

_
][
_
]

Numpy: x[
1
, 
0
]

1
][
0
]

number of

Arrays

●
Data structure with several items of the same data type


●
Seems useful for us...

類

Arrays in Python

●
We’ll use a library!


●
Why Numerical Python (NumPy)?

○
Fast & compact storage for arrays


●
Do we really need to use NumPy for arrays?

○
Yes.  See above + it’s easy to use!


40

Arrays in NumPy

>>> import numpy as np

>>> a = np.array([1,2,3])



41

Arrays in NumPy

>>> import numpy as np

>>> a = np.array([1,2,3])



"nickname" 
could be 
anything, 
np
 is 
what you will 
see most often

42

Arrays in NumPy

>>> import numpy as np

>>> a = np.array([1,2,3])



just remember 
to be 
consistent

●
# dimensions?
 
        

a.ndim



2


●
Size?
 
       



a.size



6


●
Shape?
 
        



a.shape



(3,2)

49

Arrays in NumPy

>>> import numpy as np

>>> array_example = np.array([[[0, 1, 2, 3],

                          


[4, 5, 6, 7]],

                         

  [[0, 1, 2, 3],

                          


[4, 5, 6, 7]],

                         

  [[0 ,1 ,2, 3],

                          


[4, 5, 6, 7]]])


●
Higher dimensions: hard for humans, easy for NumPy

●
To convert among str, int, float, bool...

○
Can do this for individual data values, e.g.: 
float(a)

○
Can do this across entire arrays, e.g.: 
a.astype(float)


86

Show of hands...


>>> a = np.array([[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]])

>>> b = 1.0*a

>>> b.dtype


●
Is this legal? What happens?

87

Yes it’s legal!

>>> a = np.array([[1,2],[3,4],[5,6]])

>>> b = 1.0*a

>>> b.dtype


●
Output: dtype('float64')

Filtering your data

●
Start with a data frame (called a “table” in SQL)


●
Making your table smaller = “filtering”


●
SQL commands:

○
“SELECT” = Restrict by columns

○
“WHERE” = Restrict by rows

column1
,
 column2, ...

FROM
 
table_name

WHERE
 
condition
;
